text: <@U1MFW8CFM>: bluemix currently requires this, but that is temporary. Fabric can support other means of uploading chaincode that don't require a public github repo
<@U1MNES6NR|lbonniot> has joined the channel
<@U0KM61BCP>, did you receive my email regarding use case vs. function matrix in exit criteria?  If so, thoughts?
I'm not sure where to ask this: How sandboxed is the chaincode runtime? Does the runtime _enforce_ that query chaincode functions cannot actually write anything?
<@U1LNG6E8H>: <#C0YPYBVJM>
THanks.
<@U1MQ9AWF9|wkulhanek> has joined the channel

Good morning, David Kravitz's slides on *Hyperledger Fabric - Membership Services* from the Identity WG session are available in <#C1J0BM448>. You are welcome to join. Questions/comments/suggestions/discussions/... welcome!
<@U1A6VU4JE>: likely but technically on pto this week; will look on my return
hello folks
Is hyper ledger fabric production ready?
I mean - can I take the current code and start building serious apps over it?
<@U0KM61BCP>: ok thanks, good weekend!
<@U1MRNBC3U|findthomas> has joined the channel
<@U1MPWUG2X|paypaltaurean> has joined the channel
<@U1MR9J3D2|akshay.maniyar> has joined the channel
<@U1MSSPAG1|justin.white> has joined the channel
<@U1MSZ37NK|sstone1> has joined the channel
<@U0KM61BCP> thanks...i am not using bluemix but trying to deploy hyperledger fabric in our cloud infrastructure and deploy code chain
<@U1K5R1CP9>: it really depends on the/your definition of serious apps...
Fabric is still at the `Incubation` stage (see the docs/wiki for definitions)

There is a dev-preview tag from a few weeks ago, there are issues on various platforms (ongoing development to stabilize the zLinux build, for example) and some of the underlying components are moving relatively rapidly. HOWEVER,

I believe that you should start developing against/with it, and if it's a serious application that requires loads of testing/trying/scaling, etc... the sooner you start developing, the better. I clearly don't know enough about what you are trying to do, but in general, a PoC/Mockup will give you a much better sense as for its readiness for your specific needs [And will allow you to ask us many more questions! ;-)]. There are a few companies/developers that are doing this these days already... I can tell you this.
<@U0KM61BCP> what are the  other means to uploading chaincode to Fabric besides rebuilding the peer binary with the chaincode embedded?
<@U1MUE5XEU|evicent> has joined the channel
<@U1MFW8CFM>: to be clear, you do not ever need to rebuild the peer binary to deploy chaincode

<@U0KPFAZNF>: that was one of the options proposed in stack overflow...however, I am still unclear on how to deploy chaincode that is not on public github repo. Lets say  I want to deploy something from private repo. Since deploy codechain uses `go get` I think it is kind of forcing me to have my chaincode in public github repo unless somehow peer gets the creds for private github repo
The shortest answer I can offer is to use member.deploy() from the node sdk
No peer binary rebuilds, no GitHub necessary
I'm not sure what was said on stack overflow but it sounds like misinformation
thanks <@U0KPFAZNF> it sounds like I need to use node sdk rather than `peer` cli or REST api...i was told about node sdk on #memerbship-services channel as well

People (including myself) have been confused about peers, clients, and the rest api.  But at no time was it ever necessary to rebuild the peer and the SDK exposes a more obvious path forward (even though both offer the same basic mechanism under the hood)
i think the stack overflow answer was mentioning it in context of dev setup...where you put the chaincode under `fabric/examples/go/chaincode/` and then rebuild the peer image...
but that might be just that...dev env only...
when I tried deploying from private github repo with `peer` cli then deployment failed because `go get` couldn't get the files...once I used public repo it worked....
yeah, the confusing thing is that the REST api is only meant to be used as an extension of your client to an NVP
if you think of it as an entry point to the network, the way it behaves doesnt make sense
to that point, it only makes sense if you have a client+NVP running on the same machine
in which case, the deployment that references a local file is logical
The SDK collapses the NVP function into your nodejs process, which is more natural
but regardless, even with the client+rest+nvp model, you still do not need to rebuild the peer binary
oh ok, got your point about rebuilding peer binary. i will explore the node sdk further.

<@U1MFW8CFM>: the simplest is probably to use the (public) github for now... btw, I like to view the node/sdk as one 'reference implementation' (potentially, one of many). It might be easier to start at a higher level (without building).
Happy to look at a use-case or an (updated) example code, btw.
(e.g. <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example02/chaincode_example02.go>)

attachments.title: hyperledger/fabric
attachments.text: fabric - Fabric is a blockchain project in Incubation proposed to the community and documented at <https://goo.gl/RYQZ5N>. Information on what Incubation entails can be found in the Hyperledger Proj...

the meeting was held on Wendesday

I uploaded the WG's slides there. No summary, mainly discussions around what we can already do, where we want to be etc...

(Is this what you were looking for?)
<@U1N1K0RAM|yyamashita> has joined the channel
<@U11MANG9G>: yes , it is! Thanks. I was with Christopher Allen during the meeting. Could you tell me where to find the meeting information? I'd like to join regularly
I forget to ask Christopher, sorry

<@U1N1ALR6H> Yes, of course. There was one part of the Identity WG session. There are regular Identity WG sessions regularly, not necessarily about Membership Services (see the <#C114SSX41> channel for the regular sessions/schedule/etc. ).

In a few weeks we should have another session by David - I will also post details in the <#C1J0BM448> channel about the next Identity WG session about *Membership Services*, closer to the date/when the date is set.
